reg:regulation.reg:title: Public Health Bylaws Regulation
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 255/2016, November 28, 2016]

bcl:definition.bcl:text: medical health officer means a medical health officer designated under the Public Health Act;
minister means the minister designated under the Responsible Minister Regulation, B.C. Reg. 330/2003, as the minister responsible in relation to bylaws under section 8 (3) (i) of the Act;
Nisg̱a'a Nation has the same meaning as in the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement as defined in section 1 of the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement Act;
PHSA means the Provincial Health Services Authority, a society as defined in section 1 of the Societies Act;
regional health board means a board as defined in section 1 of the Health Authorities Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restrictions and conditions on public health bylaws

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 9 (4) (a) of the Act, bylaws made by a council under section 8 (3) (i) [public health] of the Act in relation to the following matters are subject to the restrictions and conditions set out in subsection (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the protection, promotion or preservation of the health of individuals;
the maintenance of sanitary conditions in the municipality;
the restriction, or potential restriction, of any individual's access to health services;
any matter that may affect the personnel, financial or other resources of a regional health board, the Nisg̱a'a Nation or the PHSA.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), for the purposes of section 9 (4) (b) of the Act, the following restrictions and conditions apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a council may not adopt a bylaw in relation to a matter referred to only in subsection 1 (a) or (b) unless the bylaw or a copy of it is deposited with the minister;
a council may not adopt a bylaw in relation to a matter referred to only in subsection 1 (c) or (d) unless the bylaw is approved by the minister;
before adopting a bylaw in relation to matters referred to in subsection 1 (a), (b), (c) or (d), a council must consult with
responsible for public health matters within the municipality.
